awd_titl_txt: The Role of Suppressed Bone Turnover in Cortical Bone Material Composition, Organization, and Fracture Resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
Bisphosphonates are the most commonly used osteoporosis treatment that has been effective in preventing osteoporotic fractures by suppressing bone turnover. Turnover refers to the resorption and replacement of tissue. Despite the beneficial effects of bisphosphonates, there is accumulating evidence of a potential complication in the form of atypical femoral fracture. The recent reports of possible association of atypical femoral fracture with prolonged bisphosphonate use brought into attention the possibility of adverse mechanical modifications in bone due to extensive suppression of bone turnover. The overall goal of this award is to advance the understanding of the changes in material composition, organization, and fracture resistance of bone due to suppressed bone turnover via multiscale computational modeling. This project will have a broad and major impact on the society as it will provide timely information on a significant potential public health problem associated with the most commonly used drug therapy for osteoporosis. The results of the project will provide new knowledge that will establish a better understanding of the effects of osteoporosis treatments on bone quality and will help determine patients under risk of atypical femoral fracture. In addition, the research plan will integrate an active educational and outreach component that will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering.
 
This research project will significantly improve the current understanding of the changes in fundamental fracture mechanisms in bone as a result of alterations in material composition and organization due to suppressed bone turnover. The project will utilize a new fracture mechanics-based finite element modeling approach and will perform systematic and controlled evaluations at multiple scales to quantify the critical levels of material property changes that will impair the fracture resistance of bone. Specifically, the study will determine the effect of bone mineral and matrix heterogeneity on crack growth, quantify the influence of increased mineralization and accumulation of advanced glycation end products on crack propagation, and identify the critical level of microcrack accumulation in bone that will adversely affect the fracture toughening mechanisms in bone.  The novel and innovative computational evaluation approach in this research project will provide unique information that cannot be measured by experiments.

por.por_cntn:
Osteoporotic and age-related fractures are a significant public health problem affecting quality of life, morbidity, mortality, and health care costs. Bisphosphonates are the most commonly used osteoporosis treatment that has been effective in preventing osteoporotic fractures by suppressing bone turnover. Despite the beneficial effects of bisphosphonates, there is accumulating evidence of a potential complication in the form of atypical femoral fracture. The recent reports of possible association of atypical femoral fracture with prolonged bisphosphonate use brought into attention the possibility of adverse mechanical modifications in bone due to extensive suppression of bone turnover.

The overall goal of this proposal was to advance the understanding of the modifications in cortical bone material composition, organization, and fracture resistance due to suppressed bone turnover via multiscale computational modeling. The proposed approach utilized a new fracture mechanics-based finite element modeling approach and performed systematic and controlled evaluations at multiple scales to identify the tissue level modifications that may impair the fracture resistance of cortical bone. Specifically, the study determined the effect of microscale material property heterogeneity, microstructure, and microcrack accumulation on fracture toughness of cortical bone. In addition, it showed how the submicroscale mechanical response of bone was altered due to modifications in mineral content, mineral distribution, organization of the mineralized collagen fibrils, and the extrafibrillar matrix properties. The novel and innovative computational evaluation approaches developed in this research project provided unique information on how tissue level modifications affect the mechanical response of cortical bone at multiple length scales that cannot be measured by experiments. This new knowledge is expected to help understand the possible link between atypical femoral fracture and long-term bisphosphonate use.

The specific most significant results of the project showed that (1) increasing material heterogeneity improved the propagation fracture resistance of cortical bone up to a certain level after which the beneficial effects of heterogeneity were diminished suggesting a possible optimum level of heterogeneity for the bone tissue; (2) increasing material heterogeneity led to increased damage volume and a more variable distribution of damage compared to the homogeneous material distribution preventing extensive crack propagation; (3) microstructure had a significant influence on the mechanical response of cortical bone at all levels of material heterogeneity; (4) an increase in microcrack density within the  physiological range improved fracture resistance by dissipating energy irrespective of the local material distribution; (5) spatial arrangement and material properties of individual mineralized collagen fibrils and extrafibrillar matrix at the submicroscale had a significant influence on the apparent mechanical properties of mineralized collagen fibril  networks; and (6) mineral content and distribution in mineralized collagen fibrils significantly influences the submicroscale mechanical behavior.

The research project generated new knowledge that has the potential to have a broad and major impact on the society as it provided timely information on a significant potential public health problem associated with the most commonly used drug therapy for osteoporosis. The results of the project provided new knowledge that established a better understanding of the possible effects of bisphosphonate treatment on bone fracture resistance. This new knowledge has the potential to improve fracture risk assessment and therapeutic interventions. It also provides information that may help understand the underlying causes of atypical femoral fracture which may provide guidance for effective decision process on the use of bisphosphonates to reduce its potential complications and eliminate substantial health care costs. 

The educational initiatives of the proposed project broadened the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering by giving special emphasis on recruitment, teaching, mentoring, and outreach activities. The outreach programs for middle school girls, developed as a part of this project, targeted a critical age group when interest in technical fields is formed. This program impacted the middle school girls? perception of engineering and inform them about careers in engineering. This is expected to increase the number of girls who will pursue engineering degrees and help increase the diversity in the engineering field.
